creator: i.wright@elsevier.co.uk
text:
The cvs task does not work on Windows 2000.

The following message is generated:
build.xml:30: java.io.IOException: CreateProcess: 
cvs -d :pserver:xxx@yyy:/somedir/cvs checkout Common error=267

I have the cvs.exe from the cygwin package and the command line as shown in the 
error message will work unmodified when run from within the same command shell.

I have tried with 1.4.1 and the nightly build from 15 March 2002

creator: pdg@jcs.be
text: Is there already a solution for it ? (I have the same problem)

creator: jakarta@ehatchersolutions.com
text:
There is something fishy with running <cvs> under cygwin.  I can run it fine in 
a Windows command-shell, but under cygwin I get this:

checkout:
      [cvs] Using cvs passfile: C:\jakarta\.cvspass
      [cvs] cvs checkout: authorization failed: server localhost rejected access
 to /home/cvs/projects for user erik
      [cvs] cvs checkout: used empty password; try "cvs login" with a real passw
ord

BUILD FAILED

So, <cvs> does work under Windows 2000, but does not appear to under cygwin on 
Windows 2000.

creator: jakarta@ehatchersolutions.com
text:
More information: it seems that when it spawns the CVS command, that the 
environment variable CVS_PASSFILE is not being set properly.  It shows it right 
in the -debug environment dump, but perhaps there is a backslash issue?  I set 
from the command-line and ran it interactively and it works with forward-
slashes in CVS_PASSFILE, but <cvs> is settingt them with backslashes (which 
does not work for me interactively).

I switched to the cvs.exe from www.cvshome.org/downloads.html as this is easier 
to install than cygwin.
I've run this again with -debug and it would appear that the main problem was 
caused by an unset property(typo!) being used for the dest attribute therefore 
an invalid destination directory.
The default passfile is also a problem but setting a value (forward or back 
slashes) seems to solve this.
